oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Former slaves of the Wessyngton Plantation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph features four former slaves of the Washington family of Wessyngton Plantation located in Cedar Hill in Robertson County, Tenn. Featured are Allen Washington (standing) who worked as head dairyman; Granville Washington (standing) who worked as personal valet and body servant to George A. Washignton; Emmanuel Washington (seated) who worked as the cook; and Henny Washington, who worked as the head laundress.

One of the largest tobacco plantations of the South, Wessyngton was the estate of the Washington family, one of the state's largest slave owners. In 1860, the family owned 13,000 acres and 274 slaves.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: William Gustav Thuss
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Slavery; Wessyngton Plantation (Tenn.); Tobacco farms; Plantation life--Southern States--History
Tobacco plantations
